 MCALLEN - Although United States officials are working daily to prevent firearms from crossing the border into Mexico, where the violent confrontations between Mexican government forces and drug gangs continue to escalate, the effectiveness of those efforts are being called into question.
 Project Gunrunner, the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives' program that focuses on denying Mexican criminal organizations access to firearms, was reviewed by the U.S. Department of Justice last week.
 The review cited "significant weaknesses" in the efforts of ATF agents working on the southwest border.
 According to the report, one of the most significant weaknesses in the program is the inability of ATF agents to communicate with Mexican officials.
 In addition, Depart-
 ment of Justice officials criticized the com-
 munication efforts among ATF and other U.S. agencies, such as Immigration and Cus-
 toms Enforcement and the Drug Enforcement Administration. The communication issues hinder the program's effectiveness in providing intelligence and infor-
 mation to be shared among the agencies, the report contends.
 ATF Deputy Director Kenneth Melson responded to the review in a letter to the justice department expressing concerns over how his agency was evaluated in the review.
 Melson agreed with the Justice Department's recommendation for ATF to increase communication efforts with other agencies - including the Mexican government.
 "ATF has been and will continue to evaluate and refine protocols for sharing strategic intelligence with the Government of Mexico and our domestic partners," he said in the letter.
 However, Melson also asked the Justice Department to keep in mind that combating violence, gun trafficking and drug trafficking is a challenging border initiative that takes time, understanding and money.
 "There have been significant challenges given the differences between the Mexican and United States legal systems, the investigative capabilities and resources, and the culture and laws relating to firearms possession," he said.
 Mexican gun tracing was also a point of weakness outlined in the Justice Department's analysis. Melson agreed that tracing efforts have not been fruitful in Mexico, but he assured the DOJ that giving Mexican officials 64 computers, with the translated version of the U.S. tracing database, would help improve the effort.
 The report indicates the program's successes as well as as well as its shortcomings. Advantages to the program include the fact that the number of traces of U.S. and Mexican crime-involved guns has increased since the program's launch and there has been a 54 percent increase in the number of gun smuggling cases referred for prosecution in the United States.
 Overall, the ATF agreed with most of the review.
 "We are committed to building on these successes and improving the program in the areas identified by the (Office of the Inspector General)," Melson wrote.?
